Chapter:
Self-replicating groups
Introductory text. To do.
Properties and Attributes
true if G is self-replicating, and false otherwise.
The argument of this property is aa regular rooted tree group G.
gap> subgroups:=AllSubgroups(AutT(2,2)); [ Group(()), Group([ (3,4) ]), Group([ (1,2) ]), Group([ (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (1,3)(2,4) ]), Group([ (1,4)(2,3) ]), Group([ (3,4), (1,2) ]), Group([ (1,3)(2,4), (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (1,3,2,4), (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (3,4), (1,2), (1,3)(2,4) ]) ] gap> Apply(subgroups,G->RegularRootedTreeGroup(2,2,G)); gap> Apply(subgroups,G->IsSelfReplicating(G)); gap> subgroups; [ false, false, false, false, false, false, false, true, true, true ]
true if G has sufficient rigid automorphisms, and false otherwise.
The argument of this property is a regular rooted tree group G
gap> subgroups:=AllSubgroups(AutT(2,2)); [ Group(()), Group([ (3,4) ]), Group([ (1,2) ]), Group([ (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (1,3)(2,4) ]), Group([ (1,4)(2,3) ]), Group([ (3,4), (1,2) ]), Group([ (1,3)(2,4), (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (1,3,2,4), (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (3,4), (1,2), (1,3)(2,4) ]) ] gap> Apply(subgroups,G->RegularRootedTreeGroup(2,2,G)); gap> Apply(subgroups,G->HasSufficientRigidAutomorphisms(G)); gap> subgroups; [ false, false, false, false, true, false, false, true, true, true ]
The restriction of G to \mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n-1}).
The argument of this attribute is a regular rooted tree group G \le\mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n}).
gap> G:=AutT(2,3);; gap> ParentGroup(G); Group([ (1,2), (1,3)(2,4), (3,4) ]) gap> last=AutT(2,2); true
The maximal extension of M(G)\le\mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n+1}) of G.
The argument of this attribute is a self-replicating regular rooted tree group G \le\mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n}) with sufficient rigid automorphisms.
gap> G:=AutT(2,3);; gap> MaximalExtension(G); <permutation group with 11 generators> gap> last=AutT(2,4); true
A self-replicating \mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n})-conjugate of G with sufficient rigid automorphisms. If G has sufficient rigid automorphisms then the output group has the same parent group (see ) as G.
The argument of this attribute is a self-replicating regular rooted tree group G \le\mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n}).
gap> G:=SRGroup(2,3,6); SRGroup(2,3,6) gap> conjugates:=ShallowCopy(AsList(G^AutT(2,3))); [ Group([ (1,5)(2,6)(3,7)(4,8), (1,3)(2,4)(5,7)(6,8), (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (1,5)(2,6)(3,8)(4,7), (1,3)(2,4)(5,8)(6,7), (1,2)(3,4) ]) ] gap> Apply(conjugates,H->RegularRootedTreeGroup(2,3,H)); gap> for H in conjugates do Print(HasSufficientRigidAutomorphisms(H),"\n"); od; true false gap> H:=conjugates[2]; Group([ (1,5)(2,6)(3,8)(4,7), (1,3)(2,4)(5,8)(6,7), (1,2)(3,4) ]) gap> IsSelfReplicating(H); true gap> RepresentativeWithSufficientRigidAutomorphisms(H); Group([ (1,5)(2,6)(3,7)(4,8), (1,3)(2,4)(5,7)(6,8), (1,2)(3,4) ]) gap> last=conjugates[1]; true
Examples
AutT. More to come. Grigorchuk, Hanoi, ...
The regular rooted tree group \mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n}) as a permutation group of the k^{n} leaves of T_{k,n}.
The arguments of this function are a degree k \in\mathbb{N}_{\ge 2} and a depth n \in\mathbb{N}.
gap> G:=AutT(2,2); Group([ (1,2), (3,4), (1,3)(2,4) ]) gap> Size(G); 8
A list containing conjugacy class representatives of all maximal self-replicating subgroups of G.
The argument of this function is any regular rooted tree group, G
gap> ConjugacyClassRepsMaxSelfReplicatingSubgroups(AutT(2,2)); [ Group([ (1,3)(2,4), (1,2)(3,4) ]), Group([ (1,3,2,4), (1,2)(3,4) ]) ]
A list containing conjugacy class representatives of all self-replicating subgroups of the maximal extension of G, M(G).
The argument of this function is any regular rooted tree group, G
gap> ConjugacyClassRepsSelfReplicatingSubgroupsWithConjugateProjection(AutT(3,1)); [ Group([ (1,4,7)(2,5,8)(3,6,9), (1,4)(2,5)(3,6), (1,2,3), (1,2) ]), Group([ (4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (1,4,7)(2,5,8)(3,6,9), (5,6)(8,9), (2,3) (8,9), (7,9,8), (4,6,5), (1,3,2) ]), Group([ (2,3)(4,7)(5,9)(6,8), (1,4,7)(2,5,8)(3,6,9), (5,6)(8,9), (2,3)(8,9), (7,9,8), (4,6,5), (1,3,2) ]), Group([ (2,3)(5,6)(8,9), (4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (1,4,7)(2,5,8)(3,6,9), (7,9,8), (4,6,5), (1,3,2) ]), Group([ (1,7)(2,8)(3,9)(5,6), (1,7,4)(2,9,5)(3,8,6), (1,2,3), (7,8,9), (4,6,5)(7,8,9) ]), Group([ (2,3)(4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (4,6,5)(7,9,8), (1,4,7)(2,5,9) (3,6,8), (1,2,3)(4,5,6)(7,9,8) ]), Group([ (2,3)(4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (1,7,6,2,9,4,3,8,5), (1,2,3) (4,6,5), (1,2,3)(4,5,6)(7,9,8) ]), Group([ (2,3)(4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (1,6,7,3,5,8,2,4,9), (1,3,2)(4,6,5) (7,8,9) ]), Group([ (2,3)(4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (1,7,4)(2,9,5)(3,8,6), (1,2,3) (4,5,6)(7,9,8) ]), Group([ (1,4)(2,5)(3,6), (1,7,4)(2,8,5)(3,9,6), (2,3)(5,6)(8,9), (1,2,3)(4,5,6)(7,8,9), (4,5,6)(7,9,8) ]), Group([ (2,3)(5,6)(8,9), (4,7)(5,8)(6,9), (1,4,7)(2,5,8)(3,6,9), (1,3,2)(4,6,5)(7,9,8) ]) ]
